item.name: CPU busy percentage (1min)
item.description: 1 minute exponentially-decayed moving average of the CPU busy percentage

item.name: CPU busy percentage (5min)
item.description: 5 minute exponentially-decayed moving average of the CPU busy percentage

item.name: Big buffer creates
item.description: Contains the number of big buffer creates

item.description: Contains the number of free big buffers

item.description: Contains the maximum number of buffer elements

item.description: Contains the number of buffer element misses

item.description: Count of the number of buffer allocation failures

item.name: CPU busy percentage
item.description: CPU busy percentage in the last 5 second period. Not the last 5 realtime seconds but the last 5 second period in the scheduler

item.name: Free memory
item.description: Return the amount of free memory in bytes.

item.name: Contact
item.description: The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person. If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Description
item.description: A textual description of the entity. This value should include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and networking software.

item.name: Location
item.description: The physical location of this node (e.g., 'telephone closet, 3rd floor'). If the location is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE} state
item_prototype.description: The current state of the fan being instrumented

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE} memory pool Bytes free
item_prototype.description:
Indicates the number of bytes from the memory pool that are currently unused on the managed device.
Note that the sum of ciscoMemoryPoolUsed and ciscoMemoryPoolFree is the total amount of memory in the pool

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE} memory pool Bytes used
item_prototype.description: Indicates the number of bytes from the memory pool that are currently in use by applications on the managed device

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE} memory pool Bytes valid
item_prototype.description: Indicates whether or not the remaining objects in this entry contain accurate data. If an instance of this object has the value false (which in and of itself indicates an internal error condition), the values of the remaining objects in the conceptual row may contain inaccurate information (specifically, the reported values may be less than the actual values).

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE} creation time
item_prototype.description: The time when the process was created. The process ID and the time when the process was created, uniquely identifies a process

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE} dynamically allocated memory per second
item_prototype.description: The sum of all the dynamically allocated memory that this process has received from the system. This includes memory that may have been returned. The sum of freed memory is provided by cpmProcExtMemFreed. This object is deprecated by cpmProcExtMemAllocatedRev

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE} CPU utilization (5min)
item_prototype.description: This object provides a general idea of how busy a process caused the processor to be over a 5 minute period. It is determined as a weighted decaying average of the current idle time over the longest idle time. Note that this information should be used as an estimate only. This object deprecates cpmProcExtUtil5Min and increases the value range to (0..100).

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} duplex mode
item_prototype.description:
The current mode of operation of the MAC entity. 'unknown' indicates that the current duplex mode could not be etermined.
Management control of the duplex mode is accomplished through the MAU MIB. When an interface does not support autonegotiation, or when autonegotiation is not enabled, the duplex mode is controlled using ifMauDefaultType. When autonegotiation is supported and enabled, duplex mode is controlled using ifMauAutoNegAdvertisedBits. In either case, the currently operating duplex mode is reflected both in this object and in ifMauType.
Note that this object provides redundant information with ifMauType. Normally, redundant objects are discouraged. However, in this instance, it allows a management application to determine the duplex status of an interface without having to know every possible value of ifMauType. This was felt to be sufficiently valuable to justify the redundancy.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} connector present
item_prototype.description: This object has the value 'true(1)' if the interface sublayer has a physical connector and the value 'false(2)' otherwise.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} estimated bandwidth
item_prototype.description: An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in units of 1,000,000 bits per second. If this object reports a value of `n' then the speed of the interface is somewhere in the range of `n-500,000' to `n+499,999'. For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} broadcast packets inbound
item_prototype.description:
The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, which were addressed to a broadcast address at this sub-layer.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} multicast packets inbound
item_prototype.description:
The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, which were addressed to a multicast address at this sub-layer. For a MAC layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} broadcast packets outbound
item_prototype.description:
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and which were addressed to a broadcast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} multicast packets outbound
item_prototype.description:
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and which were addressed to a multicast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent. For a MAC layer protocol, this includes both Group and Functional addresses.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} promiscuous mode
item_prototype.description:
This object has a value of false(2) if this interface only accepts packets/frames that are addressed to this station. This object has a value of true(1) when the station accepts all packets/frames transmitted on the media. The value true(1) is only legal on certain types of media. If legal, setting this object to a value of true(1) may require the interface to be reset before ecoming effective.
The value of ifPromiscuousMode does not affect the reception of broadcast and multicast packets/frames by the interface.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} admin status
item_prototype.description: The desired state of the interface. The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packets can be passed. When a managed system initializes, all nterfaces start with ifAdminStatus in the down(2) state. As a result of either explicit management action or per configuration information retained by the managed system, ifAdminStatus is then changed to either the up(1) or testing(3) states (or remains in the down(2) state).

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} discarded packets inbound
item_prototype.description:
The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} error packets inbound
item_prototype.description:
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} traffic inbound
item_prototype.description:
The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} unicast packets inbound
item_prototype.description:
The number of packets, delivered by this sub-layer to a higher (sub-)layer, which were not addressed to a multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} unknown packets inbound
item_prototype.description:
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of packets received via the interface which were discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces that support protocol multiplexing the number of transmission units received via the interface which were discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol. For any interface that does not support protocol multiplexing, this counter will always be 0.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} operational state last change
item_prototype.description: The value of sysUpTime at the time the interface entered its current operational state. If the current state was entered prior to the last re-initialization of the local network management subsystem, then this object contains a zero value.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} MTU
item_prototype.description: The size of the largest packet which can be sent/received on the interface, specified in octets. For interfaces that are used for transmitting network datagrams, this is the size of the largest network datagram that can be sent on the interface.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} operational state
item_prototype.description: The current operational state of the interface. The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packets can be passed. If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2). If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic; it should change to dormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection); it should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state; it should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing (typically, hardware) components.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} discarded packets outbound
item_prototype.description:
The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being transmitted. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} error packets outbound
item_prototype.description:
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that could not be transmitted because of errors.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} traffic outbound
item_prototype.description:
The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} unicast packets outbound
item_prototype.description:
The total number of packets that higher-level protocols requested be transmitted, and which were not addressed to a multicast or broadcast address at this sub-layer, including those that were discarded or not sent.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} physical address
item_prototype.description: The interface's address at its protocol sub-layer. For example, for an 802.x interface, this object normally contains a MAC address. The interface's media-specific MIB must define the bit and byte ordering and the format of the value of this object. For interfaces which do not have such an address (e.g., a serial line), this object should contain an octet string of zero length.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} type
item_prototype.description: The type of interface. Additional values for ifType are assigned by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA), through updating the syntax of the IANAifType textual convention.

trigger_prototype.name: Inbound packet on interface {#SNMPVALUE} contained error that prevents delivery to a higher-layer protocol
Inbound packet on interface {#SNMPVALUE} was chosen to be discarded
trigger_prototype.description: One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space

trigger_prototype.name: Inbound packet on interface {#SNMPVALUE} was chosen to be discarded because of an unknown or unsupported protocol
Outbound packet on interface {#SNMPVALUE} could not be transmitted because of error
Outbound packet on interface {#SNMPVALUE} was chosen to be discarded
trigger_prototype.description: One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.

item.name: WLC Max Number Of APs Supported

item_prototype.name: AP $1 number of users 2.4 GHz
item_prototype.description: No of Users associated with this radio.

item_prototype.name: AP $1 number of users 5 GHz
item_prototype.description: No of Users associated with this radio.

item_prototype.name: AP $1 2.4 GHz channel number
item_prototype.description: Current channel number of the AP Interface. Channel numbers will be from 1 to 14 for 802.11b interface type. Channel numbers will be from 34 to 169 for 802.11a interface type.

item_prototype.name: AP $1 5 GHz channel number
item_prototype.description: Current channel number of the AP Interface. Channel numbers will be from 1 to 14 for 802.11b interface type. Channel numbers will be from 34 to 169 for 802.11a interface type.

item_prototype.name: AP $1 power level 2.4 GHz
item_prototype.description: No of Users associated with this radio.

item_prototype.name: AP $1 power level 5 GHz
item_prototype.description: No of Users associated with this radio.

item_prototype.name: AP $1 IP address
item_prototype.description: Clients (Mobile Stations)

trigger_prototype.name: AP $1 2.4 GHz is powered stronger than 5 GHz

item_prototype.name: SSID $1 number of associations
item_prototype.description: "No of Mobile Stations currently associated with the WLAN."

discovery_rule.name: WLC Clients data
discovery_rule.description: 802.11 MAC Address of the Mobile Station.

item_prototype.name: Client $1 Inbound Bytes
item_prototype.description: Bytes received from Mobile Station

item_prototype.name: Client $1 Outgoing Bytes
item_prototype.description: Bytes sent to Mobile Station

item_prototype.name: Client $1 IP address
item_prototype.description: IP Address of the Mobile Station

item_prototype.name: Client $1 RSSI
item_prototype.description: Average packet RSSI for the Mobile Station.

discovery_rule.name: WLC Interfaces data
discovery_rule.description:
You may also consider using IF-MIB::ifType or IF-MIB::ifAlias for discovery depending on your filtering needs.
{$SNMP_COMMUNITY} is a global macro.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} admin status
item_prototype.description: The desired state of the interface.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} inbound errors
item_prototype.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} inbound traffic
item_prototype.description: The number of octets in valid MAC frames received on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} operation status
item_prototype.description: The current operational state of the interface.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} outbound errors
item_prototype.description: For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that could not be transmitted because of errors. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that could not be transmitted because of errors.

item_prototype.name: iface {#SNMPVALUE} outbound traffic
item_prototype.description: The number of octets transmitted in MAC frames on this interface, including the MAC header and FCS.

trigger_prototype.name: Operational status was changed on {HOST.NAME} interface {#SNMPVALUE}

trigger.name: Buffer creation failed due to no free memory
